Mike Woodhouse wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>Part of the problem is that although I have data for 521 companies, 
>>these aren't 521 independent data sets because the price graph for a
>>    
>>
>lot of these companies is very similar.
>  
>
>
>Very good point. Another thing you need to deal with (and this is very
>tricky) is that there is an inherent bias the data set acquired by
>obtaining history: you don't have data on shares that are no longer
>traded, either because of takeover, privatisation or just plain going
>bust! So when you acquire a historical data set, you're only getting
>data for companies that have existed - largely unchanged - over the
>whole period. Don't forget share price changes due to stock splits,
>either (Mann Group, to my certain knowledge, have split 5 or 6 to 1
>this year).
>  
>

I do have data for companies that have gone bust or have been bought so 
far this year, but yes right now for my current experiment I only use 
companies that have data over the whole period that I have been logging 
(Jul '05 to the present). As for stock splits and consolidations I 
actually adjust the share price in my database so that historic prices 
are rebased to the new share structure. I noticed that some trading 
websites that provide graphs do this to their data as well - whereas 
other just log the raw data and nothing more (e.g. ft.com I think).


>>One problem I envisage with longer histories is that older data may be 
>>fairly useless in evolving a trading strategy for the present, since no 
>>doubt automated trading and semi-automatic analysis/trading has probably 
>>    
>>
>>been progressing in leaps and bounds in the last 5 years or so, thus 
>>fundamentally altering the short term dynamics of the markets. 
>>    
>>
>
>Maybe, but the bulk of the money in the markets tends to be from
>institutions such as pension fund managers, who have to find somewhere
>to invest for our retirement! Systems (IT ones) that manage
>investments are probably less likely to be effecting large changes in
>the market. The rise and rise of the hedge fund may be starting to
>have an impact, and the current environment where tidal waves of
>private equity are washing over the market must be having some
>different kind of impact as well.
>  
>

Absolutely, but these are all factors that are likely to make the market 
dynamics different to in the past. And yes a great deal of deal of money 
is managed by fund managers but I wonder how much of that trading occurs 
via semi-automated systems. E.g. A fund manager decides to buy a block 
of shares but instead of instructing a team of traders to buy he 
instructs an semi-automated trader who's job it is to trickle buy the 
shares in an optimal way. Thus the very short term dynamics are still 
being affected by algorithmic traders.


>>So on the whole it's very interesting that NEAT has found a strategy 
>>that performs really well over the provided data set, but all this does 
>>for now is provide food for thought for the next round of experimentation.
>>
>>That's the name of the game, though, isn't it!
>>    
>>

Yup. No clear signal from the extra 9 days worth of trading BTW (10 days 
minus a bank holiday). I also increased the threshold on my company 
(trading amount) filter so that I'm testing 555 companies instead of 
521. Interestingly the champ ANN has not performed any additional trades 
at all on that data set and therefore scores exactly the same. This is 
sort of positive I suppose in that it didn't make any losses. Oh and one 
of those two losing trades is a suspended share that I couldn't have 
traded at the time the signal was given (it signalled a short after a 
large fall).

Colin.
